text: this school in Hamas's where hundreds of
young men now await a decision on their
fate family members can visit them but
they can't leave many who escaped the
besieged old city already know their
future will be tough in this first room
we visit all the men have suffered
serious injuries alav√©s mandir had a 14
year old abdul karim was shot in the leg
when he was out buying bread
his father died long ago his mother died
of malnutrition he tells me he has no
one in the world I'm Ali Ali mafia
Yousef can't walk his nine-year-old
sister Miriam doesn't leave his side
there was no medical care inside the old
city he says and no food we had to eat
grass and cats families were ready to
kill for food
many men did not want to be on camera
some told us they were involved in the
fighting but they had no choice but to
come out if they stayed they would have
died now they face a different kind of
danger it's in these classrooms on the
top floor that the interrogations
involving the police and intelligence
services are taking place everyone we've
spoken to who's been through this
process say they're being asked a lot of
questions about their own activities but
also about the rebel fighters still
inside the old city and that's what made
many people uneasy about a humanitarian
mission it's also turning into an
intelligence gathering operation we saw
men going in and out of these rooms some
were told they will be freed but others
were not and they're fearful they're
being lectured here - this is called
re-education the governor tells them
we're all Syrian all on the same side
but what about the men who told us they
won't be freed Charlie and I may believe
most of the men will be cleared or be
given an amnesty they'll be free to go
wherever they wish for those who are not
they will be tried in civilian courts
the UN is keeping a close eye on what
happens here but they admit as time goes
on that may not always be possible
please - said BBC News Homs
